Scotland’s highest court rules prorogation of parliament unlawful

Scotland’s highest court has ruled that the prorogation of parliament was unlawful, reports Mure Dickie from Edinburgh.

However, it said it will not seek to recall parliamentarians before the UK Supreme Court makes a final decision on the issue.

Colin Sutherland, Lord Carloway, Lord President of Edinburgh’s Court of Session, ruled in a case brought by more than 70 parliamentarians to stop prime minister Boris Johnson from suspending parliament.

The Edinburgh court’s lower outer house had ruled last week that the prorogation was a matter of “high policy and political judgment” and not something that courts could pass judgment on.

But Lord Carloway said the inner court’s judges had agreed it was unlawful.

A draft of the court ruling said the prime minister’s decision to advise the Queen to prorogue parliament was “unlawful because it had the purpose of stymying parliament”.

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing has made a £32bn unsolicited bid to buy the London Stock Exchange Group, aiming to break up its agreed deal with Refinitiv.

HKEX has offered £20.45 a share in cash and 2.495 newly issued HKEX shares, valuing the LSE at £83.61 a share. That is a 23 per cent premium to LSE’s closing price on Tuesday. LSE shares soared more than 7 per cent to £73 on the news.

“Bringing HKEX and the London Stock Exchange together will redefine global capital markets for decades to come,” said Charles Li, chief executive of HKEX. “Both businesses have great brands, financial strength and proven growth track records. Together, we will connect East and West, be more diversified and we will be able to offer customers greater innovation, risk management and trading opportunities.”

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Market participants seem to be excited about the Refinitiv transaction - we are not. While
Refinitiv may bring long-term growth opportunities, near-term risks are evident: 1) 36%
of its revenues are in structural decline; 2) additional leverage is massive and 3) there
has been under-investment in the past. The deal looks great adjusted for all burdens,
but the reality from a cash flow perspective looks different: We expect Refinitiv to dilute
FCF to shareholders until 2024 - investors will need to hold their breath for some time
before seeing the benefits. On the back of a) euphoria on the transaction leaving room
for disappointment; b) limited growth prospects for LSEG's core business and c) not
much room for additional M&A/shareholder remuneration, we downgrade to Reduce.

BE11:21am

There are a couple of warning signs at LSEG at the moment:
1) The gap between reported and adjusted earnings is rising;
2) Revenue growth struggled with 1.6% y/y (adj. for IFRS 15 and FX) in H1 19;
3) FCF generation to shareholders has already been poor for longer: 1.9% yield in 2018 is
not much.
The acquisition of Refinitiv may open new fields of earnings growth - but what is left for
shareholders? Refinitiv is a challenged asset which brings opportunities but also significant
risk as:
a) ~36% of revenues are in structural decline;
b) group leverage at 3.4x net debt EBITDA will be high;
c) there has been under-investment in the past as well.
Hence, we expect a) FCF to shareholders (FCFE) post a 1.1% dividend yield not to exceed
2.5% until 2022 and b) the transaction to be dilutive to FCFE until 2024.

BE11:21am

Market participants are impressed about

30% adj. EPS accretion in year 1 - we are not. Our

focus remains on cash generation which will remain poor for the combined entity. We do not
expect the transaction to be cash flow accretive before 2024 due to:
a) restructuring expenses;
b) higher capex given under-investment in Refinitiv in the past;
c) pre-payment premiums for at least for Refinitiv's bonds outstanding.
Moreover, massive de-leveraging requirements in the first 24-30 months imposed by rating
agencies (Moody's put LSEG on review for downgrade) will likely absorb any FCF generation
previously used for smaller M&A transactions or share buybacks.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

The transaction looks nice on paper but there is nothing left for shareholders beside adj. EPS
accretion - a pure accounting gimmick.

Anyway, bringing us forward, Berenberg was the broker that pushed the "in play" theory the hardest post Refinitiv being announced.

BE11:24am

Here are their thoughts this morning.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

bid approach for LSE is not entirely unexpected. LSE has been the recipient of a bid approach every two and a half years since listing in 2000. Our report in July on LSE’s acquisition of Refinitiv estimated there was a one-in-three probability that the transaction would “flush out” a bidder for LSE, and highlighted Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) and CME as potential acquirers.

Tom Dalgleish Patience, Vs AUD fairly static I think unlike the Thia Baht which has been rampant
BE11:24am

[But} We are surprised that the potential acquirer is Hong Kong
Exchange, however. There is currently little operational overlap between the two groups. Transitioning Hong Kong Exchange on to LSE’s trading architecture will likely generate some cost synergies, while near-term revenue synergies may centre on LSE’s intellectual property (FTSE China index, in particular) and potential UK-China listings. Nonetheless, these pale in comparison with the synergies we expect from, say, a tie-up between ICE and LSE.

VV75 would this not bring out any interest from ICE and/or CME?
tangledodyssey nightingale20201The people in Sarawak must be dreading the thought of that, given the "konfrontasi" that M'sia had with Indonesia a few decades ago
BE11:25am

We think there are a few antitrust implications from a tie-up between LSE and Hong Kong Exchange. However .... historically it is political objections that have derailed crossborder M&A in the exchange space.

VV75 buy it now or lose the chance
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Hong Kong Exchange’s £1.4bn acquisition of London Metals Exchange in 2012 passed with only limited political comment. This deal is of a much greater magnitude, however, and impacts more politically sensitive assets: an acquisition of the LSE would see a Chinese company acquire the primary equity markets of both the UK and Italy, as well as key infrastructure for European debt markets. We believe this transaction would face elevated political risks as a result.

IMP.GLD Interested to hear Chris Hohn's thoughts
BE11:26am

The implied bid price values LSE (excluding Refinitiv) at 36.5x P/E (2020) and 18.6x EV/EBITDA (2020), for 10-11% growth in EPS and EBITDA. The implied bid price of 8,380p is close to our valuation of LSE assuming a 100% probability of the Refinitiv deal completing (8,313p). At the bid price of 8,380p we estimate the combined LSE-Refinitiv business would be valued at 26.9x P/E (2020) and 13.1x EV/EBITDA (2020) for strongly double-digit EPS growth.

BE11:26am

(@VV75: that was equally true two months ago, and two years ago, and two decades ago.)

Tom Dalgleish Traffic congestion in Jakarta is much less than 10 years ago due to Grab bikes which displaced taxis
11:26 am
BE11:26am

We expect LSE to continue to pursue the Refinitiv deal: LSE’s board faced a similar scenario in 2016 when ICE approached the group despite LSE committing to a merger with Deutsche Börse. On that occasion the board rebuffed ICE. Our initial expectation is that LSE will do the same here, opting to continue to pursue the near-term earnings-accretion and long-term strategic logic of the deal with Refinitiv.

BE11:29am

We consider the likelihood for a successful takeover as relatively low: 1) It is unlikely that US or EU regulators would allow an Asian player to gain control of critical infrastructure assets in post-trade such as LCH or CC&G or Monte Titoli as an important CSD; 2) It is unlikely that CEO Schwimmer is very keen to work as a divisional manager for HKEX CEO Charles Li. Hence, we consider a takeover of LSEG by HKEX as unlikely. We prefer Euronext in the sector which we expect to further grow via additional accretive M&A deals in Europe. Our recommendation is to Sell LSEG shares!

Synergies on such a deal would be huge (in both France and Brazil) but in many people's minds CO's assets are generally of inferior quality in France. Regulatory concerns would also feature with the overlap between the two in the greater Paris a potential formidable risk (CA leads in the wider metro area, CO in the city centre). So would their no.1 and no.2 positions in Brazil. In France, CA is overall no.2 with 20% share, and CO no.4 on 11%.

BE11:36am

So is this a breakup story that got overblown? Maybe. Kepler:

11:36 am
BE11:36am

We doubt JCN would be ready to sell at such a
price. Finally, the timing of the release is fortunate for Casino, before
Rallye starts negotiating with the banks. On Carrefour’s side, this would
highlight that the recovery plan may not be successful, thus the idea of
striking a deal (similar to Fnac Darty).

BE11:36am

All the French retailers are looking at Casino’s assets, especially since the
announcement of the EUR2bn asset disposal. As explained in our previous
note, should EUR6bn sales be for sales, everybody will try to get a fair
share just to defend their market share. From a social point of view, those
asset disposals would not lead to lay-offs, as the staff is taken over by the
buyer, and this should please the government. So far, out of the store
disposals conducted in 2018, Lidl and Leclerc were the main buyers.

cracklenpop @Tom DalgleishNo sign yet of the Grab bike effect in scooter-choked Hanoi and Saigon

Along with a conspiracy angle, which may seem interesting given the Carrefour denial, Casino no comment this morning.

Tom Dalgleish Are there many cars in Hanoi and Saigon?

11:37 am
BE11:37am

We doubt this can be done without Casino’s consent, except if under
extreme pressure from the government and the banks. From Casino’s point of view, the release of this news is fortunate, following the entry of
Kretinski (4.6% share) and ahead of the expected negotiation round with
the banks at Rallye. The first six months of the safeguard expire in
November, and we believe that Rallye needs to show that it has started
negotiations with the banks. In theory, it does not need to, but in practice it will. A higher share price is more than welcome for JCN, Casino’s CEO and owner.

tangledodyssey Casino is a mess. They have been having to close their Leader Price stores all over France, that's their low-cost chain.
BE11:38am

Bompard is a dealmaker. However, buying all of Casino implies selling and
closing a lot of assets in France. Latam will be easy to sell. In addition, this
may highlight to investors that his recovery is stalling, which would be a
negative. Feedback from Carrefour’s roadshow has been rather
disappointing so far, as the company refrain from giving any insights. We
would prefer Carrefour to cherry-pick the assets than to buy it all.Bompard is a dealmaker. However, buying all of Casino implies selling and
closing a lot of assets in France. Latam will be easy to sell. In addition, this
may highlight to investors that his recovery is stalling, which would be a
negative. Feedback from Carrefour’s roadshow has been rather
disappointing so far, as the company refrain from giving any insights. We
would prefer Carrefour to cherry-pick the assets than to buy it all.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

GBKrona mentions Aviva.

BE11:49am

AV,:LSE

Aviva PLC (AV.:LSE): Last: 397.40, up 10 (+2.58%), High: 398.50, Low: 390.60, Volume: 3.71m
AI :-D Thanks BE
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Which is of course highly likely to sell its Asia division for, what, $4bn or thereabouts.

Patience @GBKrona - prefer Legal & General to Aviva as long-term proposition.
BE11:52am

I note in passing that whenever a company is selling a division, all sorts of conversations can happen in all sorts of directions. Anyway, here's Jefferies with a push.

BE11:52am

Aviva is the only Large European insurer that trades near its 2016 Referendum low. However, herein lies the opportunity; with a market-implied Cost of Equity of 12.4% and implied growth rate of just 2.2%, Aviva has an enticing valuation and is actively addressing balance sheet concerns. Moreover, with a potential sale of Aviva Asia and CMI_2018 releases on the horizon, we believe Aviva is taking decisive steps to create a Fortress Balance Sheet.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Fortress Balance Sheet: it's capitalised.

GBKrona surely HSBC could just buy Aviva entirely to increase value added services and reinforce UK market strength
BE11:54am

Though completely counter-consensual, we believe Aviva is
decisively shifting from a weak balance sheet besieged by financial market exposure, to a Fortress Balance Sheet capable of weathering market volatility. In the near term, we believe that the possibility (not a necessity) of a disposal of the Asian franchise for as much as $4bn, and the benefit of longevity tailwinds, provide a buffer to absorb Brexit-related asset risk. In the long term, Aviva's commitment to reducing leverage, costs and non-operating expenses will leave Aviva less geared, more liquid and with higher quality earnings.

BE11:54am

A decade in the making - Consequently, in our view, Aviva is 6 to 7 years through a decade-long balance sheet shift. Beginning in 2012, Aviva re-based dividends -27%, disposed of non-core subsidiaries and began de-leveraging. This continues today, with Aviva cutting its intercompany loans, reducing external debt and weighing up more strategic disposals. Nevertheless, though the long wait has been exasperating, we believe that the current market valuation of Aviva discounts any possibility of the fruits of this transformation ever being realised

GBKrona Didn;t HSBC last week say they were increasing UK business by more competitive mortgages (which are lower margin)
nightingale20201 @Patience/GBK - LGEN has got the UK annuity market sown up, their US start up is encouraging, plus the fact they are building out their long term infrastructure play, LGIM (retails investment)
Irish HF guy Aviva, £15bn and it is yours at today's price, under £4 looks interesting. Life business makes up 96% of operating profit, all the others basically account for 4%. UK 64% of life profits. Equity is £17.5bn so trading at 86% of BV.
chopper bear soco ?
11:56 am

So as well as Asia raising about 22% of the market cap there's the chance of reviving the FPI sale and booking a load of releases on longevity assumptions, Jefferies says.

Which draws an Axa parallel post its many, many profit warnings into late 2018 and its subsequent reraating.

Irish HF guy and Aviva equity is £16.758, double counted the Tier 1 capital!
BE11:58am

Aviva currently presents investors with a similarly remarkable opportunity.
With a 2019F dividend underpin of greater than 8.5% that we do not expect to be cut, it is difficult to justify a higher yield, limiting capital downside. Undoubtedly, there is the risk of near-term macroeconomic or political upheaval that will limit the market's enthusiasm, however, we believe that investors are more than fairly compensated for that exposure with high dividends and a heavily asymmetric risk and reward opportunity.

Adjusting for the Egypt period of ownership, results were as expected, but whilst for many names this would be reassuring, SOCO trades at a premium so in our view needs to demonstrate an improved ability to exceed expectations. We reiterate our Underperform rating but look to the upcoming CMD for further detail on the upside that may exist within the portfolio.

Tom Dalgleish Irish, to your credit you did say HMSO better than INTU
BE12:03pm

Or Peel Hunt.

BE12:03pm

SOCO has released a positive interim statement this morning. Activity at SOCO’s two producing regions is progressing well, with five development wells completed in Egypt and a rig contract signed for infill wells in Vietnam. Importantly production is solid, with FY19 guidance unchanged. SOCO will host a Capital Markets Day on 29 October, where progress in 2019 and the future outlook will be discussed in more detail. SOCO has also proposed changing its name to Pharos Energy Plc, pending shareholder approval. We maintain our 120p/sh target price and Buy recommendation.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Or RBC.

BE12:04pm

SOCO has released H1/19 results this morning with numbers in-line, having pre-announced a number of key metrics. FY19 guidance remains unchanged and management is scheduled to host a Capital Markets Day on 29th October. The Company has also proposed to change its name to Pharos Energy. As previously announced production averaged ~9.9kboe/d (7.3kboe/d from Vietnam for H1/19; 5.6kboe/d from Egypt since 2nd April), generating revenue of ~$91.8m. Realisations in Egypt averaged a ~$5/bbl discount to Brent, while Vietnam averaged a ~$4/bbl premium to Brent. Operating profit of $20.7m, was in line with our $22.3m forecast, as was reported net loss of $19m and cash from operations of $54.6m in-line with our $56m forecast. Cash in hand of $66m was already announced and with $100m drawn on the RBL facility net debt $33.7m was in-line with our $31.5m forecast. FY19 Vietnam capex is expected to be $22m (already announced) and Egypt spending eased lower to $28m from $30m.

FY19 production guidance remains unchanged; Vietnam is expected to average 6,500-7,500 boe/d with Egypt production expected to exit the year at 6,500 b/d. SOCO is anticipated to provide further details at its upcoming Capital Markets Day on 29 October. The Company has proposed to change its name to Pharos Energy, with the proposal to be put to shareholders at the upcoming general meeting.

In Egypt two drilling rigs and two workover rigs remain active, and since acquisition four development wells and one injector well have been drilled. A third workover rig is due to commence work in October. The Company is also working to optimise crude off-take and sales arrangements, and has already changed to sales being made directly to the Suez Oil Processing Company. In Vietnam, planned upgrade work to the TGT compressors has commenced and is expected to complete in H1/20. Meanwhile, negotiations continue on a new FPSO Tie-In Agreement between the HLJOC and Thang Long Joint Operating Company (TLJOC); however, a further interim agreement with a new cost-sharing mechanism was put in place in August. The Borr Idun rig has been contracted to execute the 2019 work programme of two firm and two contingent infill wells. The first of the two firm wells, the TGT-H5-31I injector well, is due to spud in November 2019.

SOCO, in partnership with Cairn Energy and Israel's Ratio Oil Exploration, were successful in their bid for eight blocks in the second offshore bid round in Israel. Each party has an equal working interest with Cairn operator. Licences are to have an initial term of three years with a pair of two-year extension options. The minimum work programme includes re-evaluation of the acreage by integrating all available data, and reprocessing of 3D seismic data over high-graded prospects in each Zone. There are no firm commitment wells in the first licence phase.
